column4: easier question: what command do i type in the grub command line to list the available hard drives?
you could do a 'find vmlinuz-2.6.15'; that will tell you where bootable kernels of that version are
'geometry' might help, too, as might 'help'
you also need to give it an initrd
i don't know what that means
do a 'find initrd' and feed one of the resulting files to grub with 'initrd /initrd-2.6.15-whatever' before you type 'boot'

strange -- is this an ubuntu installation?
it sounds like you may have accidentally deleted vital part of the root system...
well, first of all, you shouldn't edit /boot/grub/menu.lst~ -- that's a backup copy.
then, the part of the file that says "AUTOMAGIC KERNELS LIST" is not supposed to be edited.
to remove those options, you should remove the unused kernel packages
